customData.content: 61-year-old female veteran with hypertension presented with chronic cough, dyspnea, 50-pound weight loss, and three weeks of nausea and vomiting. Physical exam revealed cachexia, scleral icterus, jaundice, dry mucous membranes, decreased breath sounds in the left lower lung fields, tachycardia, and hypotension. Bowel sounds were normal without pain, distension, or organomegaly. Non-smoker.

HPI.summary: 61-year-old female veteran presented with chronic cough, dyspnea, 50-pound weight loss, and three weeks of nausea and vomiting.

customData.content: Hyponatremia (sodium level of 131 mEq/L), bicarbonate level of 32 mEq/L, elevated alkaline phosphatase level of 215 u/L, total bilirubin level of 5.8 mg/dL, aspartate aminotransferase level of 58 u/L, and alanine aminotransferase level of 36 u/L.

Computed tomography of chest: innumerable pulmonary parenchymal nodules throughout both lungs with a large mass extending into the lingula as well as the superior segment of the left lower lobe. Pleural effusion around the mass. Axial chest imaging showed innumerable pulmonary parenchymal nodules throughout both lungs with a large peripherally located, 5.0 x 4.0 cm mass with a central area of necrosis and extensive involvement of the paratracheal and left hilar lymph nodes contiguous with the mass. The mass extended into the lingula as well as the superior segment of the left lower lobe with surrounding consolidation likely post-obstructive pneumonitis.

imaging.finding: innumerable pulmonary parenchymal nodules throughout both lungs
imaging.impression: innumerable pulmonary parenchymal nodules throughout both lungs with a large mass extending into the lingula as well as the superior segment of the left lower lobe. Pleural effusion around the mass.

imaging.finding: large peripherally located, 5.0 x 4.0 cm mass with a central area of necrosis and extensive involvement of the paratracheal and left hilar lymph nodes contiguous with the mass.
imaging.impression: large peripherally located, 5.0 x 4.0 cm mass with a central area of necrosis and extensive involvement of the paratracheal and left hilar lymph nodes contiguous with the mass.

customData.content: Abdominal ultrasonography: severely dilated common bile duct and a moderately distended gall bladder.

imaging.finding: severely dilated common bile duct and a moderately distended gall bladder

customData.content: Computed tomography: large heterogeneous mass in the pancreatic head (approximately 4.5 cm), grossly dilated common bile duct, enlarged retroperitoneal lymph nodes contiguous with the mass. Metastases to the brain.

Biopsies of the lung mass and pancreatic head: cell clusters with high nuclear pleomorphism and prominent nuclei. Immunohistological staining positive for thyroid transcription factor−1 (TTF-1) and cytokeratin-7 (CK-7), negative for tumor protein 63 (p63). Suggesting lung adenocarcinoma as the primary origin.

imaging.finding: cell clusters with high nuclear pleomorphism and prominent nuclei
imaging.impression: Suggesting lung adenocarcinoma as the primary origin.

imaging.finding: cell clusters with high nuclear pleomorphism and prominent nuclei
imaging.impression: Suggesting lung adenocarcinoma as the primary origin.

data.content: Patient's initial presentation followed by lab results indicating hyponatremia, elevated bicarbonate, alkaline phosphatase, and total bilirubin levels.
Following abnormal lab results, a CT scan of the chest reveals pulmonary nodules and a large mass in the left lung.
Following the chest CT, abdominal ultrasonography reveals a dilated common bile duct and distended gallbladder.
Following the abdominal ultrasound, a CT scan reveals a mass in the pancreatic head, dilated common bile duct, enlarged retroperitoneal lymph nodes, and brain metastases.
Following imaging, biopsies of the lung mass and pancreatic head suggest lung adenocarcinoma as the primary origin based on immunohistological staining results.
